comments.commentBody:
Well, a genuine DNF for me -- and all because I had GOESON for 23 down and SOBBED for 24 down and those just refused to budge. Grr. I could put it to not getting much sleep in the Berkshires, starting the puzzle on the train back to NYC from Albany, and a bit of dyspepsia from diner cuisine ... but those are kvetches.

Anyway, I thoroughly enjoyed meeting "Martin" and KS in the blog column -- I think the guest solve invite is a great idea, and look forward to the next "victim".... :)

IRIDIUM (35A) is not in the platinum group. It is in the cobalt group. It is next to Pt (at. no. 77 and 78) but that puts it in the same *period*, not the same *group*, which is a vertical stack. I hope my chem students don't do crosswords.... It sure threw me, as nickel, palladium and darmstadtium don't fit!

Thanks for the nice comments, everybody! Mean old lady from Conway, Ark., will you send me an email? vicfleming (at) att (dot) net

It's about the Ark. Puzzle Festival.

I will not say hurray for a new spelling of hooray.  Thanks to it I was not able to nor capable of breaking the SW. Allele stumped me too.  How can you put such a dad-blasted obscure word in a puzzle? This is nuts.  Will, the rascal, should have edited it out.  But I did get Sam the Sham.  Proud of that.

I finally downloaded it at @10:15 but found it slow-going - my first Saturday puzzle. The long entries were a challenge but finally doable. I don't get ICE for "number in a pack" or SAM THE SHAM, nor did I ever hear of dadblasted... I like learning new words - ALLELE, I got from the other words...

Nathan Hale in Chicago was a surprise - I spent a lot of time in New London, CT - I remember his statue at the top of Main St. - my grandfather planted 2 blue spruce there @100 years ago - I wonder if they're still there...

Hope we have more guest solvers...

I was rocking along pretty well on the bottom, getting GLASSY-EYED and ASPHALT TILE early on. ALLELE fell from somewhere in my brain. But the northwest just killed me. I threw down PATRONIZE for LET HAVE IT, thinking I was quite clever. Too many non-baseball sports references in one corner.

I did like seeing two 60s era rock groups in the same corner, but a nit to pick. SAM THE SHAM should be Pharoahs' head, since there were more than two people in the band. But what fun would that be.

Still, I'm steadily progressing on Friday/Saturday puzzles getting up to about 65-75% of what once was a bleak landscape.

Neat idea to have guest solvers write.

Laurie #30,

I was not suggesting you were a vampire - I was suggesting that the AGW leadership exposed by Climategate, were vampire-like (mysterious, hidden, an enigma, not what they seemed, needing to maintain certain conditions to be viable, etc ... and equally susceptible to 'sunlight' shining into their doings and opening up their tribe's world.

Ledeen is a brilliant writer, thinker and analyst, he does accept the need for war in certain cases and is not bashful to say what he thinks and why. Unlike the IPCC and related 'Climategaters', he is transparent and honest about where he stands. I don't need to agree with him in everything he thinks to use his signature sign-off with attribution.

Best Wishes
Speaking of EPL news, looks like Landon Donovan is seriously considering a return to Everton: http://cosbysweaters.com...

Laurie, on Ledeen, you misrepresent him:

"Michael Arthur Ledeen (born Los Angeles, California, August 1, 1941) is an American specialist on foreign policy. His research areas have included state sponsors of terrorism, Iran, the Middle East, Europe (Italy), U.S.-China relations, intelligence, and Africa (Mozambique, South Africa, and Zimbabwe) and is a leading neoconservative.[1] He is a former consultant to the United States National Security Council, the United States Department of State, and the United States Department of Defense. He has also served as a special adviser to the United States Secretary of State. He held the Freedom Scholar chair at the American Enterprise Institute where he was a scholar for twenty years and now holds the similarly named chair at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies. He is a contributing editor to National Review, contributes to the Wall Street Journal, and regularly appears on Fox News and on a variety of radio talk shows. He has been on PBS's NewsHour and CNN's Larry King Live, among others.[2] He is a founding member of JINSA and serves on their Board of Advisers.

In 1974, Michael Ledeen moved to Rome where he studied the history of Italian Fascism. In 1977, he went to Washington to join the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) (then affiliated with Georgetown University). He continues to visit Italy frequently.

In 1980, Ledeen worked for the Italian military intelligence service as a "risk assessment" consultant.[3] In 1981, Michael Ledeen then became Special Adviser to secretary of state Alexander Haig.

Ledeen holds a Ph.D. from the University of Wisconsin–Madison, where he specialized in Modern Europe. At Washington University in St. Louis, Ledeen was denied tenure, according to history department faculty interviewed by the Washington Post, because of questions regarding the "quality of his scholarship" and about whether Ledeen had "used the work of somebody else without proper credit". One faculty member said "the 'quasi-irregularity' at issue didn't warrant the negative vote on tenure for Ledeen".[3]

Ledeen was subsequently named Visiting Professor at the University of Rome. One of Ledeen's principal mentors was the Jewish German-born historian George Mosse, for whom he was research assistant at the time. Mosse wrote two famous books on National Socialism. Another major influence on Ledeen was the Italian historian Renzo De Felice. Ledeen held political views which stress "the urgency of combating centralized state power and the centrality of human freedom"[4] that are said to have influenced or inspired the Bush administration.

From your wiki link.

ALSO:

An interview with Ledeen:

http://archive.frontpagemag.com...

Best Wishes

Girma (28) - well said. Anyone wanting to understand climategate's meaning, rather than indulging in introspective drivel, would be well advised to:

1. Read the emails.
2. If searching for "context" (the typical defense being "oh, they are being taken out of context), read Montford's "Hockey Stick Illusion", and the Mosher/Fuller "The CRUtape letters".

Very simple.

Andy -

I just looked back and 8 out of the last 9 Dot-Earth posts are climate-related. This is *more* "predictable than I'd like" (A somewhat obtuse emails tie-in :) )

I think the emails did help broaden the conversation away from 24-7 CO2, CO2, CO2. Hopefully concerns about water, energy, food, and climate impacts (not just CO2 related) can be discussed in a more balanced and integrated way moving forward.

Looking forward to any and all future posts,

Cheers
I just love you arm chair amateur climatologists.
I actually am proud that I finished a Saturday before midnight.  Well, almost.  I am stumped as to the meaning of 27D.  Can someone help me out?   Thanks
Oh, DUH,  I must have had too much wine.  Just got it, sorry!!!

Really like the guest commenter series and look forward to more. If I ever stumble into NOHO (19A) while looking for Soho, I'm definitely asking directions to the No Idea bar to see if I can coax some play-by-play commentary from the owner/barkeep about the making of this tour de force beauty.

That's a fifteen yard penalty for unnecessary roughness on the clue for ICE (27D). My cortex was already numb from so many other head shots.

I suspect that neither Messrs. DiPietro nor Shortz are gearheads. For those of us who have earned our grease monkey merit badges, tank-to-carburetor conduits (33D) are FUEL LINES, not PUMPS.

Immediately thought of Buddy Ebsen for 7D.

My deceased brother worked for the MTA as an iron worker at the Tiffany yard.  He worked for six weeks on what he called "The pile".  When he was diagnosed with lung cancer three years later we all new why.  He had  a red badge that allowed him to areas even off limits to his boss at the MTA.  I remember asking him if he had used a mask at the site while he cut beams for the rescue workers.  He said he had done so but always had to remove it to speak to the firemen and of course to drink water.  At the end of every day of course his work clothes would be covered with Trade Center dust.  When it was clear to him that he would likely die from this exposure, I asked him if he would have done the work knowing the outcome.  His reply to me was "Yes because it was the right thing to do".  He left five children and five grandchildren without much of an inhertance.  It appears likely half of them won't need much parental financial help in their lives.  But the other half will be much impacted by his loss as they are less prepared for the future he might have been able to help them with.  I don't believe they are even included in this settlement.  But as  I reflect on the correctness of whether we should pay such funds to these workers ... as they were not only fire and police ... and recalling Whitman's  assurances of how safe it was.
I am reminded of his words : "the right thing to do"
The most deserving people to sue the government are the families of men and women who died/maimed fighting for an unjust cause in Iraq.

To be insensitive is one thing but to be insensitive and clueless is another.

For all the posts here that think that is was about greed and others who say that the people working at ground zero were there because they wanted to be there for overtime I wonder about that. I was a first responder on 9/11 in the days and weeks after that fateful Tuesday morning. I was not there for the OT and I would have preferred to be home with my family rather than working 7 days a week for weeks.
The dangers of one’s job are not in question and this action hardly represents a sad precedent. The question of the city, state and local govt claiming that the air we were breathing was safe while knowing that it was far from safe is in question. The fact that the men and women were not given the available adequate protection in the days following 9/11 is unquestioned. The argument that the sicknesses that have fallen on many of these first responders have yet to be proven is true, and maybe they will never be proven. How can one definitively say how and when someone developed cancer? They can’t! What can be said is that when so many young men and women have fallen victim to numerous ailments, including rare cancers in a rate that is much higher than normal is a conclusion that can be made. Aside from dealing with minor breathing problems that developed in the weeks following 9/11 I am very fortunate. The men and women who are suffering from serious cancers and the ones who have died from cancers that their own doctors attribute to their time at ground zero are less fortunate.

So for all you armchair critics who were sitting on a safe sofa glued to the news coverage of the event while hundreds of first responders gave their lives, maybe you should instead just post a thank you. Better yet, how about hundreds of get well cards to those who will be sick or dying this holiday season because of their unselfish actions 9 years ago.

Some of their illnesses are not going to surface for a time and they will require close annual screening to catch lung and throat cancers, mesothelioma and other problems before they become life-threatening and difficult to treat. I hope they have an advisor in the field of public and environmental health following them. They are going to need that for the rest of their lives as a result of their extraordinary generosity on and after September 11, 2001.
I can't believe all of the negative comments here. Looks like 9/11 has indeed faded into the past.

If you look at this closely it is a travesty of justice and shows just how out of control our compensation system is.  Every cancer, every breathing problem, high blood pressure, chronic fatigue, mental illness, everything is apparently the fault of 9-11.  Is every single issue a worker developed in the years since 9-11 the result of breathing dust?   This is compensation seekers run amok.  The real travesty are the details of the settlement and how apparently every single known medical problem is now simple to solve.  Apparently 9-11 dust causes everything.  We no longer have to do any medical research because we now know that all diseases are caused by dust.

After reading through the heartless comments from people here I am officially ashamed that they are Americans.  Perhaps they should round up the rest of their right-wing cronies and move to some remote Lord of the Flies island where they can all ignore each others' needs.  The rest of us, the real Americans, we take care of our own.
9/11 was a false flag event. The victims' families were quickly paid hush money. The $625 million should be paid out of the money made by insider trades in the business days immediately before 9/11.
Oh, I don't know...maybe a national health plan with the public option would have settled up all this with no muss or fuss about nine years ago...but hey, that is not how we do in the US of A.
I'm disgusted! And they call these people 9/11 heroes???
